text: [Music]
hey guys thomas joseph here with another
kitchen conundrum for you today we're
delving into the science behind the
pound cake now pound cake gets its name
originally from the pound of flour pound
of butter pound of sugar and pound of
eggs that goes into each and every loaf
but today I'm gonna show you that dense
version that classic pound pound pound
pound cake and a lighter version that
has a little bit of Lebanon and some
dairy in it the basic recipe is all the
same so starting off in my stand mixer I
have a pound of butter so that's four
sticks of butter and to that I'm going
to add a pound of granulated sugar now
this is two and a quarter cups of
granulated sugar for a pound cake
without added leavener if you wanted
that dense dense version you need to
cream this mixture together for eight
full minutes and what that does is it
incorporates air which then leavens the
load so the butter and sugar has been
creaming together for eight minutes you
can see how light and fluffy it is it's
a pale pale yellow and this is the first
step in leavening the pound cake
incorporating all of this air into the
butter and the sugar now the next
ingredient that will incorporate air
into your pound cake are the eggs and
again it's a pound of eggs so that's
nine whole large eggs on medium speed
now it's very important that you add
them one at a time so that they evenly
incorporate if you dump them all in it
once they're not gonna create the volume
you need and also they're going to
curdle your batter so one at a time so
I'm adding the last egg here and I'm
just going to give the bowl a little bit
of a scrape now pound cakes first
originated in England and are said to be
the first known butter cakes of which
all butter cakes originated so those
wonderful yellow cakes that you're
making for birthday parties apparently
originated from this pound cake recipe
this is nicely incorporated you can see
the mixture is not curdled it's not
chunky at all it's nice and smooth and
now I'm going to add the flavoring so I
have two teaspoons of vanilla extract
but you could make this any flavor you'd
like so vanilla extract in so now for
the dry ingredients I have a pound of
flour here this is all-purpose flour and
that is three and a quarter cups of
flour to that I'm going to add salt
which is very important when you're
baking that's two teaspoons of coarse
salt and if you were making the dense
version of this pound cake you wouldn't
need to add any lemon or but I'm using
this today because I want a lighter
pound cake so I am using three teaspoons
of baking powder a good rule of thumb
whenever you have a recipe that uses
flour and baking powder 1 cup of flour
to 1 teaspoon of baking powder so I'm
gonna sift this together make sure
you're nice and thorough here and for
the final ingredient I'm using 3/4 of a
cup of sour cream that's at room
temperature the added dairy really helps
to give you a moist flavorful cake and
in the end it proves to be a lighter
cake as well so now I'm going to add my
flour in in two additions alternating
with my sour cream that means half the
flour goes into the butter egg mixture
here and start up on low speed and while
this is incorporating you can add in a
sour cream
now the acidity that's in the sour cream
really does help to react with the
baking powder that gives you an even
lighter more leavened pound cake and now
I'm going to add the rest of the flour
until it's just combined
here we have our wonderful light batter
I like to use a scale here because I
really like to portion out the batter
evenly so that I get to uniform loads
and also so none of the batter actually
rises over the pan and into the oven
have prepared - 9 by 5 loaf pans with
butter and flour this will ensure that
the loaves will come out nice and
smoothly and that they will have a nice
brown exterior crust now with an offset
spatula like this just give the batter a
nice smooth top and make sure your oven
is preheating to 325 degrees and these
lobes will bake in the middle of the
oven so situate your rack in the middle
of the oven for about 70 to 75 minutes
and these go right into the oven the
pound cakes have been out of the oven
first you need to cool them in their
pans on a wire rack for about 30 minutes
and then you can take them out and let
them cool completely on a wire rack
these are nice and room temperature I
want to show you how they slice so
beautifully by preference really is a
lighter pound cake but whether you like
it dense like this version here which is
very classic and traditional or you
prefer something that's lighter like the
version I have here light fluffy a cake
like crumb it's all up to you now you
have the master recipe and you can make
a dense or a light pound cake there you
go enjoy
